title: How to reflect on what Plato is saying about the truth in the “Allegory of the Cave” - Quora

response.answer_text: I like the way you asked this question: not “tell me what it means,” but “how can I reflect” on what Plato might be saying. There are multiple angles from which we might probe the allegory; here’s one that hasn’t been mentioned yet. Plato’s character Socrates introduces the allegory by saying something like “compare the effect of education on our souls to something like this.” Then he describes the prisoners in the cave, what might happen if one were freed, the painful journey to the light, etc. You might reflect on your own experience of education: —Who or what “turned” you toward the light, or helped you see that what you thought was true might not be the whole story? —Why does Plato depict it as a painful struggle? Has that been your experience? —What is it like to go back down in the cave? (Do people laugh, like they do at the philosopher in the story?) —Do you believe, as Plato says, that “the power to learn is in everyone’s soul”? If so, what nurtures that power and what drains it? This may not be the kind of answer you were looking for, but I do think one fruitful way to engage with the allegory of the cave is to think about it as what Socrates says it is: an allegory about the process of education.

Truth is scary to human, we prefer to live in a comfortable darkness instead of facing the light. But a life without light is just a semi life. We have to be brave and choose the truth in every occasion, truth to others and truth for ourselves. It’s hard, as we can see in the original text, in the light people are working, in the dark they’re just listening and observing the shadows. So you have to fight back pain and lazyness if you decide to live your life truly.
